vulvodynia.definicao: Pain in the vulva that may or may not be brought on by touch or pressure.

wall stress.definicao: Force on the wall of the heart muscle caused by pressure inside the heart's pumping chamber; excessive wall stress can impair the heart's ability to pump and increase the heart's need for oxygen.

warfarin.definicao: An anticoagulant drug that prevents blood clotting; people taking it must have regular blood tests to determine that their blood does not clot too readily or too slowly.

wart.definicao: An abnormal fibrous growth caused by a viral infection.

water brash.definicao: Salty-tasting salivary secretions stimulated by gastroesophageal reflux.

weber test.definicao: A hearing test that uses a tuning fork to diagnose one-sided hearing loss.

wernicke-korsakoff syndrome.definicao: An irreversible state of acute confusion and amnesia that develops in alcoholics as a result of malnutrition-related thiamine deficiency.

wernicke's area.definicao: The brain region responsible for the comprehension of speech.

whiplash.definicao: The popular term for muscle and ligament damage resulting from rapid and extreme extension and flexion of the neck. The term is also used for the accident causing the injury, most often a rear-end motor vehicle accident.

white matter.definicao: The inner portion of the brain, composed primarily of axons, each surrounded by a myelin sheath that insulates the nerve fibers (and appears white). Messages are sent between different regions of the brain (gray matter) via these nerve fibers.

white-coat hypertension.definicao: Blood pressure that is elevated in a doctor’s office but is normal at home.

will.definicao: A legal document that describes what should be done with a person's assets after his or her death.

withdrawal.definicao: A response to danger or stress characterized by apathy, lethargy, and depression; or the physical or psychological response to a sudden lack of an addictive substance such as alcohol or nicotine.

working memory.definicao: A type of short-term memory process that involves temporarily storing and manipulating information.

xanthoma.definicao: A yellow, lipid-laden deposit in the skin or on a tendon.

yag capsulotomy.definicao: A laser technique to correct blurred vision caused by cloudiness that may develop in the skin of the cataract left in the eye after cataract surgery; a laser is used to create a hole in the membrane to allow light to enter clearly focused onto the retina.

yohimbine.definicao: An extract of the bark of a West African tree sometimes used in treating erectile dysfunction. Yohimbine appears to increase blood flow to the penis and prevent blood from leaving it too quickly.

zonules.definicao: Thin, gelatinous ligaments that attach the lens to the ciliary body and support the lens centrally behind the pupil.

zoonotic disease.definicao: An infectious disease that is transmissible under normal conditions from animals to humans.

abdomen.definicao: The abdomen is actually just another word for your stomach.

adenoids.definicao: Part of the immune system, lymph nodes at the back of your nose, above your tonsils. If they’re too large and causing breathing problems, you may need to have them removed.

adolescence.definicao: When you’re too old to be a child and not old enough to be an adult. We usually use the word adolescence to describe the time when you’re a teenager.

alopecia.definicao: This is when you lose some or all of your hair. This can be caused by medicines or it can be due to an autoimmune disease, where the body becomes mis-programmed and attacks itself rather than a foreign invader, such as a germ.

ambulance.definicao: The vehicle that brings you to and from hospital. There are two types – one is an emergency response vehicle, which contain all the equipment to look after you immediately after an accident. The other type does not contain so much equipment but takes you to and from hospital appointments.

anaemia.definicao: A condition where your red blood cells cannot carry enough oxygen. It makes you feel tired and you may look pale. There are lots of different types of anaemia – some are more serious than others.

anaesthetic.definicao: If you're under an anaesthetic, you won't feel any pain during a test or an operation. It's a special mixture of drugs, which can be breathed or injected. A general anaesthetic will let you 'sleep' while everything's going on, so you won't feel anything or know what is happening.

anaesthetist.definicao: An anaesthetist is a specially-trained doctor who will look will make sure you 'sleep' safely during an operation or test, and make sure that you get better afterwards. They also help manage your pain after surgery.

anatomy.definicao: The science of where everything is in your body and how it is formed.

angiogram.definicao: This is a special X-ray picture of an artery - that's the vessel that takes blood from your heart to the rest of your body.

antenatal.definicao: The period of time before a baby is born. For instance, antenatal screening is used to find out if the baby is alright before it is born.

antibiotics.definicao: Bacteria (germs) can sometimes make you ill and sometimes you need antibiotics to treat it. Antibiotics are medicines that attack bacteria that are making you feel unwell. Although they hurt the bacteria, they won't hurt you. Antibiotics don’t work again other infections from viruses or fungi.

antihistamines.definicao: If you've got an allergy, antihistamines can help to stop a bad reaction. They're usually tablets but sometimes you might be given a syrup, because it is easier to swallow. You can also get antihistamine cream that you put on your skin.

apnoea.definicao: A condition where you stop breathing – usually only for a few seconds. Some people have apnoea only when they’re asleep.

appendix.definicao: A little tube attached to your large intestine that has no function at all! It’s about 9cm long in adults and doesn’t usually cause any problems, unless it becomes infected – which is called appendicitis.

arteries.definicao: Our bodies contain lots of blood, which moves around in arteries, veins and capillaries. Arteries carry blood away from the heart to the rest of your body. They are made up of different layers in a tube.

atresia.definicao: This means that a passage or canal in the body is closed up at one end instead of being like a tube. There's lots of different types of atresia, which all happened while the baby was developing in the womb.

audiology.definicao: The study of hearing. An audiologist is a person who studies your hearing and can suggest ways of improving it if you have problems.

autoimmune.definicao: This is a kind of disease where the body gets confused and starts attacking itself because it thinks it’s dangerous. For instance, in arthritis, the body identifies the tissue in the joints as being ‘the enemy’ and so attacks them causing damage.

axilla.definicao: This is just a word doctors use for your armpit.

barium.definicao: This is a substance that shows up well on x-rays. It can either be swallowed or put up your bottom so the doctor can see your digestive system and check for any abnormalities.

birthmark.definicao: This is a mark on your skin that is there when you are born or develops very soon afterwards. They can be brown, red or even a blue colour.

bladder.definicao: Your bladder is a bag made of muscle, which holds urine (wee) until you go to the toilet.. The amount of urine the bladder holds varies from person to person – some people's bladders can hold a lot of urine, other people's don't hold as much.

blood.definicao: Your blood flows all around your body through arteries, veins and capillaries. It's made up of different types of blood cell – red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets – all suspended in a liquid called plasma.

blood count.definicao: A test on a sample of blood that counts how many of each type of blood cell is present. It’s used as a general check that you are well or not.

blood gases.definicao: A test that shows the amount of certain gases, like oxygen and carbon dioxide, are in your blood. It’s usually used to check whether you’re breathing effectively and getting enough oxygen.

blood groups.definicao: There are lots of different blood groups – A, B, AB and O – and everyone has one. Blood groups are important if you’re having a blood transfusion, as certain blood groups won’t be accepted if you have a different one to the donated blood.

blood sugar level.definicao: This means the amount of glucose (a form of sugar/carbohydrate) in blood.

blood transfusion.definicao: A way of replacing blood lost during an operation or after an accident. Before you have a blood transfusion, you’ll have your blood group checked to make sure your body will accept the transfusion.

blushing.definicao: This is a normal reaction to being embarrassed, or sometimes scared. The tiny blood vessels in your cheeks swell to let more blood through, which is what makes you go red.

bone.definicao: These make up our skeleton. Bones are made from substances like calcium and phosphorus which make them strong. Inside some of our bones is bone marrow.

bone marrow.definicao: You never actually get to see your bone marrow but it is very important. It's thick, squishy stuff that produces special blood cells that can develop into any sort of blood cells protect you against infection and makes sure oxygen gets to every corner of your body.

brain.definicao: The main organ in your nervous system. It’s where you think, speak and have feelings. It also controls lots of other things in your body, like breathing and temperature, which happen without you having to remember to do them.

breathing.definicao: How you take in oxygen from the air around us, and transfer it into your blood where it can travel all around your body.

bronchi.definicao: These are the two tubes that connect the bottom of your windpipe to your lungs.

bronchodilators.definicao: A type of drug used if you have asthma. They work by opening up the passages in your lungs so you can breathe easier. You usually take them using an inhaler or ‘puffer’.

bruise.definicao: We all get bruises if we knock ourselves on something or fall over. Bruises happen because the tiny blood vessels just under the skin burst so that the blood leaks out a bit. This is what makes your skin go blue. As a bruise is healing, the area goes yellow, which shows that the body is breaking down the blood and getting rid of it.

café au lait spot.definicao: A type of birthmark which is the colour of milky coffee, hence the name.

cannula.definicao: A cannula is an extremely thin plastic tube that is put into a vein to give medicines or fluids or take sample of blood.

carbohydrates.definicao: A group of substances found in food that the body converts into energy. Food containing carbohydrates include starchy foods such as potatoes, rice, pasta and bread.

carbon dioxide.definicao: A gas, which we breathe out into the atmosphere. Its chemical symbol is CO2

cardiology.definicao: The study of the heart and how it works. The specialist doctor who looks after your heart is called your cardiologist.

cast.definicao: Having a cast on a broken bone will hold it in one position so it heals right. Casts can be made from a lot of different materials, including plaster, fibreglass, plastic and even air. When your bones are better, the doctor will remove your cast, but don't worry, it doesn't hurt.

cerebral palsy.definicao: A group of disorders where a person’s brain is damaged in during childbirth or early childhoodoften by not receiving enough oxygen. This means that the person may have stiff muscles, jerky movements and problems with co-ordination. They may also have speech problems.

cerebrospinal fluid.definicao: This is the fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cordand and acts as a cushion. It’s often called CSF.

cerebrum.definicao: The main part of your brain where most of your thinking happens. It’s split into two parts (hemispheres). While we know how the brain is formed, we still don’t really understand how it works.

chemist.definicao: Also known as a pharmacist – this is the person who can advise you on medicines and supplies them to you either with or without a prescription.

chicken pox.definicao: An infectious disease that makes you break out in tiny blisters which then form scabs. These blisters are often very itchy and it can be difficult not to scratch them. When you have chicken pox you should stay away from people with low immune systems as chicken pox can cause quite severe problems for them.

clavicle.definicao: The medical word for your collarbone – the ridge you can feel from your shoulders to in front of your neck.

cleft lip.definicao: This is where a baby is born with a vertical split in their lip. It can affect one side of the lip or both. It happened while the baby was developing in the womb and can be fixed in an operation. Sometimes a baby can have both a cleft lip and a cleft palate.

cleft palate.definicao: This is where a baby is born with a split in the roof of their mouth. It happened while the baby was developing in the womb and can be fixed in an operation. Sometimes a baby can have both a cleft lip and a cleft palate.

coccyx.definicao: The four lowest vertebras in your back and they’re the leftovers from our tails before we developed into humans!

cold.definicao: A cold is a type of viral infection that causes a runny nose and a sore throat. There’s no cure for a cold, but you can take medicines for the symptoms.

cold sore.definicao: This is caused by the herpes virus, and makes a sore spot around your mouth that can weep pus and then scab over. They’re quite catching – so don’t kiss anyone with a cold sore, because you might catch one too!

colostomy bag.definicao: A pouch which is used to collect poo from a stoma (an opening made by a doctor) in a patient who is no longer able to poo naturally.

congenital.definicao: Congenital means ‘present at birth’, that you have a problem or illness from the time you were born.

consent.definicao: The legal term for when you agree to something happening.

consultant.definicao: A consultant is a senior doctor who has had lots of training and has extra knowledge about one type of illness or treatment.

contagious.definicao: If you're contagious, it means that anyone around you can catch your illness. This is more common than you might think - colds are contagious, because you can catch them from someone else.

contraception.definicao: This is a way of stopping a woman getting pregnant. There are lots of different sorts of contraception – you can find out more about them from your doctor or family planning clinic.

cough.definicao: A reflex action to clear your airway. You could do this because of a blockage of some sort, or because your lungs are clogged up with mucus when you have a cold.

cramp.definicao: This is when your muscles go into spasm and hurt. They’re really common and usually happen if you’ve kept the muscle tightened and in the same position for a long time. You can get writer’s cramp, which is when the muscles in your hand seize up when you’ve been writing for a long time. You can get rid of cramp by massaging or stretching the muscle that is in spasm.

cystic fibrosis.definicao: A disease that affects the lungs and intestines, by clogging them up with heavy sticky stuff called mucus. People with cystic fibrosis have to have regular physiotherapy to get the mucus out of their lungs and also have to take lots of tablets each day.

cystoscopy.definicao: A test that lets the doctor look inside and around your bladder.

day surgery.definicao: If you come in for a test or an operation and go home the same day, you’ve had day surgery. More and more tests and operations are done like this as you’re more likely to get better quickly when you’re at home with your family.

deafness.definicao: This is when a person cannot hear – either completely or partly. Hearing aids can help some people with deafness, or cochlear implants are used for some people. Deaf people often communicate using a sign language called BSL (British Sign Language).

death.definicao: When the body stops working completely – the person has died. This means that the heart has stopped, the person is not breathing anymore and the brain has switched off.

dehydration.definicao: If you don't have enough water in your body, you can feel very unwell. When you sweat, you lose water and it's easy to get dehydrated when it's hot, so you need to drink plenty of water. You can also lose a lot of water when you’re sick with diarrhoea and vomiting.

dentist.definicao: A person who is trained to look after your teeth and gums and fix any problems if they occur. There are also dentists who specialise in fitting braces to straighten teeth.

dermatology.definicao: The study of the skin and skin diseases.

diagnosis.definicao: This is the label that a doctor gives your symptoms, so that they can work out how to treat you.

dialysis.definicao: This is a way of removing waste products from the blood when your kidneys aren’t working properly. There are two types: haemodialysis and peritoneal dialysis.

diarrhoea.definicao: When you’ve got diarrhoea, you’ll have very runny poo and will need to go to the toilet a lot. Remember to drink lots of fluids – this will stop you feeling worse.

dietetics.definicao: The study of how what we eat can affect our health. Dietitians are the people who check what we eat and suggest ways of improving our diet so we can feel healthier. They also make up special diets for people with diseases that affect their eating.

digestive system.definicao: This consists of your oesophagus, stomach, duodenum, small bowel, large bowel, and rectum. Its job is to break down the food you eat so the goodness can be absorbed and get rid of the waste stuff as poo.

donor.definicao: A person who gives something like blood or organs to another person.

dose.definicao: The amount of medicine you are supposed to take at a certain time. You should always follow the dose instructions your doctor or pharmacist gives you – taking too much or too little medicine can be dangerous.

dyslexia.definicao: People who have trouble reading because the words jump about on the page have something called dyslexia. They may also write certain letters backwards or spell words wrong all the time. Teachers are getting much better at spotting children with dyslexia now, so they can make learning easier for you.

ear.definicao: This is what you hear through. There are three bits to your ear – the outside bit which you can see, the middle bit which is the passage from your ear hole to your ear drum and then the inner bit which is where sounds are turned into nerve messages for your brain.

earache.definicao: This is often a sign of infection, but it may not be your ears that are infected. Sometimes when you have a sore throat, you also get earache too.

eating disorder.definicao: This is a condition that affects a person’s eating behaviour and is damaging to a person’s physical and mental wellbeing. The most common kinds of eating disorder are Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia.

echo.definicao: This is short for Echocardiogram and it uses sound waves to show a picture of your heart and how it is beating. It also shows how blood is flowing through your heart.

embryo.definicao: For the first eight weeks when a baby is developing in the womb, it’s called an embryo. It only starts to look human from about the eighth week onwards, before that it looks a bit like a tadpole.

endocrinologist.definicao: An endocrinologist is a doctor who cares for children who have difficulties with their hormones.

epiglottis.definicao: This is a flap of tissue in your throat that is normally open to let air flow into your lungs. When you eat, it flops down to cover your windpipe to stop food and drink getting into your lungs. When something ‘goes the wrong way’, this means that your epiglottis has let some food or drink into your windpipe by mistake and you need to cough to get rid of it.

epilepsy.definicao: It's a type of brain disorder where your brain 'short circuits' so the electrical messages travelling to and from the brain are disrupted.

epileptic seizure.definicao: A physical reaction to a sudden burst of extra electrical activity in the brain. The type of seizure that a person has depends on where in the brain this activity happens.

eye.definicao: This is what you see with. It’s made up of different parts – including the cornea, iris, pupil and retina – and is connected to the brain by the optic nerve.

faeces.definicao: The medical word for poo. Once all the water and goodness has been absorbed from what you eat, faeces is all that’s left.

failure to thrive.definicao: The diagnosis often given to babies and children who are not getting enough nutrition from their food. This could be due to not eating enough or in some cases, to the goodness in food not being absorbed properly by the intestines.

fainting.definicao: Temporary loss of consciousness due to a lack of oxygen in the brain. If you feel faint, you should sit down and lean forwards, with your head between your knees. This will encourage blood to flow towards your brain.

fasting.definicao: Not eating or drinking. Some people fast for religious reasons. In hospital, you have to fast for a certain amount of time before an anaesthetic.

fetus.definicao: A baby developing in the womb. Before the eighth week, the baby is called an embryo. While the baby is developing in the womb, it will grow from about 2.5cm long to a final length of 51cm long.

fistula.definicao: This is an abnormal connection (or hole) that happens between an organ, vessel, skin or intestine. They can occur as a result of injury, surgery or infection.

fixator.definicao: The name for a device that holds together a bone by pins that are inserted through the skin into the bone and held in place by a surrounding brace. It can help a broken bone to heal correctly but can also be used to lengthen a bone by gradually pulling the cut ends of the bone apart so that new bone forms in the gap.

foot.definicao: Your foot is made up of 26 bones by the time you’re an adult and the largest one is your heel bone. Your feet are important because they help you stand and walk upright and they’re also vital for walking.

foreign body.definicao: Anything that is in your body, either inside or in one of the openings, that shouldn’t be there is called a foreign body. Choking is usually caused by a foreign body. You should never try to remove a foreign body yourself – this is a job for experts!

freckles.definicao: Freckles are just small patches of skin containing melanin or pigment, the substance that gives us colour. Freckles usually appear when you’re out in the sun. People with fair or red hair tend to have more freckles than dark haired people, and so should take care not to burn by using a sun block cream.

gastroenterology.definicao: The study of your digestive system. A doctor who specialises in disorders of the digestive system is called a gastroenterologist.

gastroscopy.definicao: This is a test that is used to look at inside your stomach. An endoscope (a thin bendy tube) is passed through your mouth and down your foodpipe into your stomach. If you’re awake when you have a gastroscopy (you can have it under general anaesthetic) it can give you a bit of a sore throat afterwards.

gastrostomy.definicao: A way of feeding where feed goes directly into a tube in your stomach bypassing your mouth and throat.

general anaesthetic.definicao: The name of a medication that sends a patient to sleep and stops them feeling pain during a surgical procedure by blocking signals from nerves to the brain.

germ.definicao: Germs cause diseases. There are different types of germ, including viruses and bacteria.

glue ear.definicao: This is a really common illness in children. Fluid builds up inside the middle ear and goes sticky like glue. This stops the little bones in the ear from moving about which makes it difficult to hear. It usually clears up on its own, but you may need a small drainage tube put into your eardrum called a grommet.

granulocyte.definicao: This is a type of white blood cell – there are three types of granulocyte – neutrophils, basophils and eosonophils.

grommet.definicao: This is a small drainage tube that is used to treat glue ear.

haem-.definicao: If a word begins with ‘haem’ this usually means that it is something to do with blood. For example, haematology is the study of blood.

haematuria.definicao: If you have blood in your wee, the doctors may say that you have haematuria. It’s usually caused by an infection in your urinary system. Sometimes, the amount of blood is so small, that you can only see it under a microscope.

haemoglobin.definicao: This is what makes red blood cells red. It’s a kind of pigment that carries the oxygen to all parts of your body. Each red blood cell contains about 350 million haemoglobin molecules!

hand.definicao: Your hands are really important – they help you hold things, grip things tight and also do small fiddly tasks too. What makes us different from animals is that we have something called ‘opposable thumbs’, which means that we can touch our thumb and fingers together to hold things. Like your foot, your hand is made up of lots of small bones.

heart.definicao: This is the pump made of muscle inside your ribcage that keeps us all alive. Your heart pumps all the time to push blood around the body.

hemi-.definicao: This means 'half' as in hemi-nephrectomy – an operation where half of your kidney is removed.

hip.definicao: Your hip is the joint between your pelvis and your thighbone. It’s a ‘ball and socket’ joint which means you can move your leg in all directions.

holter monitor (24 hour ecg).definicao: A Holter monitor is a portable device that monitors the electrical activity in your heart over a 24-hour period. It involves putting stickers on your chest that link up to a recording device. This then monitors your heart rate, the shape of the complexes (in other words how each beat of your heart looks) and gives a very clear picture about how your heart rhythm is working.

humerus.definicao: Your upper arm bone. It connects your shoulder with a ‘ball and socket’ joint and with your elbow with a ‘hinge’ joint.

hyper-.definicao: When this starts a word, it means ‘too much’ of something.

hypo-.definicao: When this starts a word, it means ‘too little’ of something.

ilieum.definicao: The final and longest section of the small intestine that absorbs goodness from what we eat and drink. It is attached to the colon.

immune system.definicao: This is what fights off infections. When you’re born, antibodies that are passed on protect you from your mum. As you grow older, you develop your own antibodies.

immunisation.definicao: All the injections you’re given when you’re growing up are designed to protect you against diseases. It’s important that you have all your immunisations at the right time. Some of them are given as a series of injections, where you have one when you’re a baby and then others as ‘boosters’.

incontinent.definicao: The term used to describe somebody who cannot control the release of urine or poo from their body.

incubator.definicao: This is a device used to care for babies, especially those that are born early. The incubator does this by allowing health professionals to control the temperature, humidity and oxygen around the baby.

infant.definicao: In medical terms, this is a baby up to a year old.

inhaler or nebuliser.definicao: Being able to breathe is very important but asthma can sometimes make it more difficult. If you have asthma, running about or eating certain foods can irritate your airways and make it harder for you to breathe. An inhaler is a special gadget that sprays medicine into your mouth. It help you to relax and breathe more easily. A nebuliser delivers medicines into your lungs in a form that you breathe.

inheritance.definicao: This is how genes pass on characteristics from your mum and dad to you. When red hair ‘runs in the family’, this means it has been passed on to you through your parents’ genes. Characteristics can also ‘jump’ generations, your parents may not have red hair, but maybe your granddad did! Certain diseases are also passed on from your parents. There are different kinds of inheritance – some kinds means you’re more likely to inherit a disease.

intestine.definicao: This is part of your digestive system. You have a large intestine (also called the colon) and a small intestine (duodenum, jejunum and ileum). They work together to squeeze food through to your bottom, absorbing liquid and goodness along the way.

intramuscular.definicao: A type of injection that is given into a muscle.

intrathecal.definicao: A type of injection that is given into the spaces between the bones in your spine.

isotope.definicao: A kind of dye that contains radioactivity so shows up on scans.

-itis.definicao: If a word ends in ‘-itis’, it means that a part of your body is inflamed. For example, cystitis means that your bladder is inflamed.

iv or intravenous.definicao: An IV (intravenous) drip allows you to get the nutrients your body needs into your system through your veins when you're unable to actually eat or drink. It's also a way of getting medicines into your system when you can’t eat or drink – some medicines also work better this way.

larynx.definicao: The medical word for voice box – the part of your throat that produces sound.

large bowel.definicao: This is also called your colon and is where any water from your food is absorbed to form poo.

laxatives.definicao: Medication taken to stimulate a bowel movement and relieve constipation. In other words, it helps you have a poo.

lens.definicao: The part of your eye that lets you focus what you see so it is clear.

leukaemia.definicao: A type of cancer that affects your blood cells.

lungs.definicao: You usually have two of these, on either side of your chest inside your ribcage. When you breathe in air, it travels down the windpipe through the bronchi, into your lungs. When you breathe in, your lungs expand, and when you breathe out, they go back to their normal size. Your lungs are full of little bags (alveoli) which remove oxygen from the air we breathe in, and put carbon dioxide into the air we breathe out.

lymph.definicao: This is a fluid that circulated in the lymphatic system. It's full of lymphocytes – white blood cells which fight infection.

mandible.definicao: This is your lower jaw bone that holds your bottom teeth in place and forms your chin.

manometry.definicao: A test that shows how well nerves and muscles in the digestive system are squeezing to push along food or waste matter.

maxilla.definicao: The bones in the skull that form your upper jaw are called the maxilla.

measles.definicao: This is a serious disease that affects mainly children. It causes a rash and a high temperature and can cause inflammation of the brain. Most children are immunised against measles now, by the MMR jab, but children who have not been immunised are at risk. If a pregnant woman catches measles, it can cause a miscarriage.

microscope.definicao: A powerful instrument that lets scientists examine things closely that cannot normally be seen with the naked eye.

migraine.definicao: A serious headache, usually with sickness as well. Some people cannot see properly when they have a migraine. A migraine can last from a couple of hours to a couple of days. They can be treated with painkillers and often by lying in a darkened room.

molecule.definicao: The smallest part of a substance.

morphine.definicao: This is a medicine that is used to relieve pain.

mouth ulcer.definicao: This is a sore patch inside your mouth. Mouth ulcers are really painful, and are made worse if you eat or drink something acidic like lemon squash. They can be treated using gels you can buy from your chemist.

mri scan.definicao: A magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan produces images of what's going on inside your body. It uses very strong magnetic fields (like a big magnet) and radio waves. An MRI scanner looks like a tunnel that you lie inside. It takes a while but you can watch a video or listen to music while you're in there, so it's not that as bad as it sounds. You do have to lie very still though, but it doesn't hurt at all.

mucus.definicao: This is a thick, slimy fluid released by the mucous membranes.

mumps.definicao: A seroius illness that mainly affects children. Most children are immunised against mumps now, by the MMR jab, but children who have not been immunised are at risk.

muscles.definicao: We have lots of muscles in our body – some are very small, others are very big. Muscles work by contracting (squeezing tight) and relaxing to make things move.

nasogastric tube.definicao: A tube that is passed up your nose, and down your throat to your stomach. It’s used for draining off what’s in your stomach, or for feeding if you can’t swallow.

nausea.definicao: Feeling sick, or wanting to puke, isn't very nice. Nausea is the word that doctors sometimes use to say this.

nephrology.definicao: The study of kidneys and diseases that affect them. The doctor who specialises in nephrology is called a nephrologist.

nervous system.definicao: This is just another way of describing your brain and spinal cord and the nerves connected to it.. It works like a modem, sending signals around your body. It tells your brain when you touch something. If something's hot or cold, a signal zooms from your fingers up to your brain.

neurology.definicao: The study of the brain and nervous system.

neurosurgery.definicao: Any operation on the brain or nervous system. The doctor who does the operation is called a neurosurgeon.

nuclear medicine.definicao: This is a type of scan that uses radioactive dye that will show up on images. The amount of radioactivity in the dye is tiny – much less than you’d get from a normal x-ray.

nystagmus.definicao: This is an eye condition where your eyes move about, usually from side to side. You can’t control this movement, it’s just something that happens.

occupational therapist.definicao: Sometimes, when you've been sick, it can be difficult doing things like you used to. An occupational therapist is someone who will help you to get used to doing everyday things again - such as doing up your laces or getting on with your schoolwork.

oesophagus.definicao: This is sometimes called your foodpipe. When you've swallowed your food, it travels to your stomach through this tube. It works by squeezing rhythmically to push the food downwards.

operating theatre.definicao: This is where you'll go to have an operation (surgery).

operation or surgery.definicao: Sometimes the doctors need to be able to get inside your body to make you sort out problems that you're experiencing. Most operations are carried out under an anaesthetic, which means you won't be awake or know what is happening.

ophthalmology.definicao: The study of your eyes and diseases that affect them. The doctor who specialises in ophthalmology is called an ophthalmologist.

oral.definicao: This means your mouth. Some medicines have to be swallowed – these are called oral medicines.

orthodontist.definicao: The name of a dentist who specialises in straightening or moving teeth.

orthopaedics.definicao: This is the study of bones. Doctors who operate on your bones are called orthopaedic surgeons.

pacemaker.definicao: A pacemaker gives off electrical signals if your heart isn’t beating regularly.

paediatrics.definicao: The study of children’s development and the diseases that affect children. A doctor who specialises in paediatrics is called a paediatrician.

paracetamol.definicao: Paracetamol helps to stop things from hurting. It can also make reduce swelling and stop you feeling as hot. You should only ever take paracetamol according to the instructions on the bottle.

pituitary.definicao: This is a gland (a tiny organ) deep in your brain that makes lots of hormones (chemical messengers that turn on and off processes in the body.

platelets.definicao: These are the smallest types of blood cell, which helps make your blood clot when you cut yourself.

postnatal.definicao: The period of time after a woman gives birth.

premature birth.definicao: The term used to describe babies that are born before 38 weeks of a mother’s pregnancy.

premedication.definicao: Premedication or 'premed' is a special medicine that you are sometimes given before an operation (surgery). It's usually a liquid that you can drink and it helps to stop you worrying about the operation. Some types of pre-med help to dry up your mucus too.

prescription.definicao: The note that a doctor writes to a pharmacist to tell them what medicines you need and in what dose.

radiography.definicao: Making pictures using radioactive materials, like x-rays.

radiology.definicao: The study of making pictures using radioactive materials, like x-rays.

radius.definicao: One the bones in your arm, on the side of your thumb.

rash.definicao: A mark on the skin that is usually red and sore. It may also be itchy. Rashes happen if you’re allergic to something and goes away quite quickly. A rash can sometimes be a sign of disease too, such as measles.

recovery room.definicao: Most people are usually 'asleep' under a general anaesthetic during an operation (surgery). It takes a while for you to wake up afterwards. Usually you'll wake up in the Recovery Room, a special room where the nurses will give you extra special care. When you're feeling a bit more awake, you'll go back to the ward.

red blood cells.definicao: Red blood cells carry oxygen from your lungs to cells around your body.

Traduções.es: las células rojas de la sangre *

reflex.definicao: An automatic response to something. For instance, a doctor checks your reflex by hitting a special part of your knee that makes your leg move upwards.

rehabilitation.definicao: The word used to describe the process of returning somebody to full health or fitness.

respiratory system.definicao: This consists of your trachea (windpipe), bronchi and lungs. Its job is to take the oxygen out of the air you breathe so it can be absorbed by the body.

resuscitated.definicao: This describes a person who has been successfully revived after they had previously stopped breathing of their heart had failed. This is generally done using cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR, see entry).

rubella.definicao: Another name for German measles, an infectious disease that mainly affects children. Most children are immunised against rubella now, by the MMR jab, but children who have not been immunised are at risk. If a pregnant woman develops rubella, the baby can be born deaf and blind.

saliva.definicao: The fluids that flows into your mouth from your salivary glands and the mucous membrane inside your mouth. It makes swallowing easier as it makes the food mushy.

scab.definicao: A crust that forms on your skin or a mucous membrane if you’ve been injured. It’s made up of clotted blood and pus.

scapula.definicao: The medical name for your shoulder blade.

scar.definicao: A mark that’s left on your skin after an injury or operation.

sclerotherapy.definicao: A method of shrivelling up blood vessels by injecting a medicine.

-scopy.definicao: A test that let the doctor look at the inside of part of your body. There are lots of different types of test, like a gastroscopy which involves your stomach and a cystoscopy which involves your bladder.

sedation.definicao: A way of making you very sleepy, usually before and during a test or procedure.

sibling.definicao: Another word for your brother or sister.

skeleton.definicao: Our skeleton is what keeps us all in one piece – it's a bit like scaffolding. It's made up of over 200 bones, which range in size from the tiny bones in our ear, to large bones like our thighbones.

small bowel.definicao: This is part of your intestines and is about six metres long. It's all coiled up inside your abdomen. The small bowel's job is to remove the goodness from your food so that it can be absorbed by your body.

sneezing.definicao: When you want to sneeze, nothing will stop it! It’s a response to something irritating your nose or airway. When you sneeze, it’s important to catch it in a hankie or tissue.

snoring.definicao: If you breathe very noisily when you’re asleep, this is called snoring.

spinal cord.definicao: This is part of your central nervous system. Your spinal cord is about 45cm long and about as thick as your finger. Messages to and from your brain travel down the cord before being passed on to other parts of your body.

spleen.definicao: Your spleen is where red blood cells that are worn out and destroyed. It’s also part of your immune system.

splint.definicao: A method of keeping part of your body in one place while it heals. For instance, if you break a finger, it may be splinted to the next finger to keep it in one place so you can’t bend it until it heals.

stem cells.definicao: These are the immature cells in the bone marrow that can turn into the specific type of cell the body needs. Stem cells can be transplanted from one person to another to cure a disease.

symptom.definicao: A sign of a disease or condition that the patient notices and reports to a doctor.

syndrome.definicao: A collection of symptoms often seen together.

thorax.definicao: The medical word for your chest.

tonsils.definicao: You have tonsils on either side of your throat at the back of your mouth. They’re part of the immune system. When you’re a child, they can become inflamed which is called tonsillitis.

trachea.definicao: The medical word for your windpipe.

tumour.definicao: A growth of some kind. These days, it usually refers to a lump of cells that are growing in an uncontrolled way.

twins.definicao: When two babies are born together, they’re twins. You can be an identical twin, which means the twins developed from the same egg, or non-identical twins which means that two eggs were fertilised at the same time.

ulna.definicao: One of the bones in your arm on the opposite side of your arm to the radius.

ultrasound scan.definicao: This scan uses sound waves instead of x-rays to show your insides. It's very like the scan most women have when they're pregnant.

urine.definicao: The medical word for wee. It’s a mixture of water and other waste products and is produced by your kidneys.

urinary system.definicao: This consists of your kidneys, ureters, urethra, and bladder. They all work together to get rid of the waste stuff (wee) from your body.

urology.definicao: The study of your urinary system. Doctors who specialise in urology are called urologists.

veins.definicao: These are blood vessels that carry blood back to the heart from the rest of your body. They are made up of different layers in a tube, like arteries, but are not as strong.

ventilation.definicao: If you can’t breathe on your own after an operation or an accident, you may be put onto a ventilator. This is a machine that does your breathing for you.

virus.definicao: A type of germ that can cause disease. Viruses cause colds, and more serious diseases like meningitis. Antibiotics don’t work against viruses so there’s no point in taking them for things like a cold.
